title: 109_s3238
content: The Act is titled the "NASA and JPL 50th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act" and specifies the coin specifications. The "NASA and JPL 50th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of $50 gold coins and $1 silver coins to commemorate the 50th anniversary of NASA and JPL. The $50 gold coins will weigh 33.931 grams and contain 1 troy ounce of fine gold, while the $1 silver coins will weigh 26.73 grams and contain 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. The coins minted under the "NASA and JPL 50th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act" are legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary of the Treasury can mint and issue up to 400,000 of each of the 9 $1 coins authorized by the Act. The curr_chunk is about the design of coins. The design of coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the achievements of NASA and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Each coin will feature the coin's value, the year 2008, and inscriptions like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". Additional inscriptions may be added as determined by the Secretary. The $50 coins issued under this Act will feature the sun on the obverse and a design representing the sacrifice of US astronauts on the reverse. The edge will bear names and dates of spacecraft missions where astronauts lost their lives. The design will be in high relief. The $1 coins issued under this Act will feature 9 different designs on the obverse, each representing a planet of the solar system including Earth. The reverse will have designs emblematic of discoveries and missions of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory to the respective planet. The $1 coins issued under this Act featuring Earth on the obverse will honor NASA missions, Earth-orbiting missions, and Apollo missions on the reverse. The $1 coins issued under this Act featuring Jupiter and Saturn on the obverse will include scientifically accurate depictions of their respective moons Europa and Titan, along with past and future missions to Europa. The reverse of the $1 coins issued under this Act featuring Pluto will show an emblematic design of telescopic exploration by NASA and the search for Earth-like planets. The designs of $1 coins should bear names, dates, or mission types related to the planet depicted on the obverse. Images must be realistic, scientifically accurate, and reminiscent of the artwork from the "Golden Age of Coinage" in the United States. Noted sculptors and artists like James Earle Fraser and Augustus Saint-Gaudens will be involved in the selection process. The design for coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with NASA, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, and Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coin Advisory Committee. Symbolic inclusion of metals flown in space. The Federal agencies and institutions of the United States, including NASA and the Department of Defense, must retrieve metals from spacecraft for use in producing coins as determined by the Director of the US Mint. The metals retrieved should be deposited with the Director of the US Mint for coin production. The metals retrieved from spacecraft by Federal agencies and institutions, including NASA and the Department of Defense, must be deposited with the Director of the US Mint for use in producing coins. The metals will be blended with other necessary metals to create coins with a proportion of bullion from space crafts, and accurate records must be maintained for authenticity certificates. The US Mint will provide certificates of authenticity with coins made from metals retrieved from spacecraft, along with a list of missions the craft flew in space. Federal agencies must make efforts to secure metals from privately-held spacecraft for coin production, as determined by the Mint Director. Federal agencies and instrumentality of the United States should comply with recordkeeping procedures when retrieving metals from privately-held spacecraft that have flown in space. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in proof quality only at a designated Mint facility starting January 1, 2008, with minting authority ending on December 31, 2008. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing. Prepaid orders will be accepted at a discount, and the Secretary will determine appropriate presentation methods for the coins. The Secretary will provide a presentation case for the $50 gold coin surrounded by $1 silver coins in an elliptical orbit. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. All sales of coins minted under this Act include a surcharge: $50 per $50 coin and $10 per $1 coin. Surcharges received are distributed to the NASA Family Assistance Fund and the Smithsonian Institution for specific purposes. The National Air and Space Museum, including the Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center, receives funding for the preservation and display of space artifacts. A portion of the funds is allocated to the Smithsonian Institution for the National Numismatics Collection, and another portion goes to the National Numismatic Preservation Foundation for numismatic collectibles. The NASA Family Assistance Fund and the Smithsonian Institution are subject to audit requirements for the funds they receive. The limitation on surcharges for commemorative coin programs issued under the Act is outlined in subsection (d). No surcharge can be included if it would exceed the annual issuance limitation. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide guidance for this provision. The Secretary is authorized to strike and sell bronze duplicates of the $50 gold coins at a price determined to be appropriate.
